qkit.analysis.circle_fit.circle_fit_advanced package

Submodules

qkit.analysis.circle_fit.circle_fit_advanced.circle_fitter module

@author: Wridhdhisom Karar ,2024

inspired by and based on resonator tools of Sebastian Probst https://github.com/sebastianprobst/resonator_tools

class qkit.analysis.circle_fit.circle_fit_advanced.circle_fitter.CircleFitter(f_data, z_data_raw=None, delay=None, power=0)[source]

Bases: object

Base class for common routines and definitions shared between both ports.

inputs: - f_data: Frequencies for which scattering data z_data_raw is taken - z_data_raw: Measured values for scattering parameter S11 or S21 taken at

frequencies f_data

classmethod Sij(f, fr, Ql, Qc, phi=0.0, a=1.0, alpha=0.0, delay=0.0)[source]

Full model for S11 of single-port reflection measurements or S21 of notch configuration measurements. The models only differ in a factor of 2 which is set by the dedicated port classes inheriting from this class.

inputs: - fr: Resonance frequency - Ql: Loaded quality factor - Qc: Coupling (aka external) quality factor. Calculated with

diameter correction method, i.e. 1/Qc = Re{1/|Qc| * exp(i*phi)}

  • phi (opt.): Angle of the circle’s rotation around the off-resonant

    point due to impedance mismatches or Fano interference.

  • a, alpha (opt.): Arbitrary scaling and rotation of the circle w.r.t.

    origin

  • delay (opt.): Time delay between output and input signal leading to

    linearly frequency dependent phase shift

autofit(calc_errors=True, fixed_delay=None, isolation=15, prefit=None)[source]

Automatically calibrate data, normalize it and extract quality factors. If the autofit fails or the results look bad, please discuss with author.

no need to pass delay if given during init,

prefit, gets the fit results from the previous fit, and uses it as a guess for the current fit suitable for higher powers, where the Ql changes and the Qc changes, and the radius changes

calc_fano_range(isolation=15, b=None)[source]

Calculates the systematic Qi (and Qc) uncertainty range based on Fano interference with given strength of the background path (cf. Rieger & Guenzler et al., arXiv:2209.03036).

inputs: either of - isolation (dB): Suppression of the interference path by this value.

The corresponding relative background amplitude b is calculated with b = 10**(-isolation/20).

  • b (lin): Relative background path amplitude of Fano.

outputs (added to fitresults dictionary): - Qi_min, Qi_max: Systematic uncertainty range for Qi - Qc_min, Qc_max: Systematic uncertainty range for Qc - fano_b: Relative background path amplitude of Fano.

fit_result(plot=True, prefit=None)[source]

Returns the fit results as a dictionary.

get_photons_in_resonator(power=0, unit='dBm', diacorr=True)[source]

returns the average number of photons for a given power in units of W unit can be ‘dBm’ or ‘watt’

get_single_photon_limit(unit='dBm', diacorr=True)[source]
returns the amout of power in units of W necessary

to maintain one photon on average in the cavity unit can be ‘dBm’ or ‘watt’

classmethod phase_centered(f, fr, Ql, theta, delay=0.0)[source]

Yields the phase response of a strongly overcoupled (Qi >> Qc) resonator in reflection which corresponds to a circle centered around the origin. Additionally, a linear background slope is accounted for if needed.

inputs: - fr: Resonance frequency - Ql: Loaded quality factor (and since Qi >> Qc also Ql = Qc) - theta: Offset phase - delay (opt.): Time delay between output and input signal leading to

linearly frequency dependent phase shift

plotall()[source]
plotcalibrateddata()[source]
plotrawdata()[source]

Circlefit class for two-port resonator probed in transmission.

n_ports = 2

qkit.analysis.circle_fit.circle_fit_advanced.circuit module

@author: Wridhdhisom Karar (w.karar.1@research.gla.ac.uk) / 2024

inspired by and based on resonator tools of Sebastian Probst https://github.com/sebastianprobst/resonator_tools

an update to all the circle fit models - iterative with scipy-curvefit / gradient based - iterative with lmfit - algebric moments method - ML,model based (yet to implement)

qkit.analysis.circle_fit.circle_fit_advanced.helper_functions.data_smoother(x, sigma)
qkit.analysis.circle_fit.circle_fit_advanced.helper_functions.soft_averager(z_data_raw: ndarray, averages: int = 20) → ndarray[source]

A iterative soft averager to remove the noise from the data and smoothen out noisy data for low power resonator data to improve fitting at low photon numbers.

It samples the raw data ,spaced evenly/unevenly and accumulates averaging it over the number of averages and then returns the averaged data

qkit.analysis.circle_fit.circle_fit_advanced.resonator module

class qkit.analysis.circle_fit.circle_fit_advanced.resonator.PowerResonator(Sij, f: list, power=[0], **kwargs)[source]

Bases: object

Power Resonator class holds a resonator model information Ideally complex S21/S11 data at different power levels Attributes: 1. fr: float -> Resonance frequency 1a. _fr: float ->frequency Range 2. Ql: float -> Loaded/External Q 3. Qc: float -> Coupling Q 4. Qi: float -> Internal Q 5. Sij: [complexIQ]/(amplitude,phase) -> Sij data ; either for a single power or multiple power levels 6. Pow: float -> Power level 7. Temp: float -> Temperature 8. photon: float -> Number of photons/ corresponding and calculated from power level

Methods : 1. __init__ : Constructor

  1. generate(nop=5000, start_f, stop_f,fr,fano_b) : Generate the resonator model from the given parameters

  2. generate_mw_model(nop=5000, start_f, stop_f,fr,fano_b) : Generate the resonator model from the given parameters using scipy.mw

  3. save(filename) : Save the model to a file using pandas

  4. plot() : Plot the model

  5. load(filename) : Load the model from a file using pandas

Note: # powers < the freqeuncy span of the resonator either 1D or 2D Sij data

class qkit.analysis.circle_fit.circle_fit_advanced.resonator.Resonator(Sij, f: list, fr: float = 5000000000.0, nop: int = 1001, pow=0.0, Qi: float = 1000000.0, Ql: float = 1000000.0, Qc: float = 50000, temp: float = 0.026)[source]

Bases: object

Theretical Resonator class holds a resonator model information Ideally complex S21/S11 data

  1. either store measured data and fit it, will update the fitparams

    1. calculates the model params

    2. Calculates SNR

    3. Photon number

  2. or generate the model with some preset parameters

    1. set the desired parameters

    2. generate the model will update the Sij based on the parameters

Attributes: 1. fr: float -> Resonance frequency 1a. _fr: float ->frequency Range 2. Ql: float -> Loaded/External Q 3. Qc: float -> Coupling Q 4. Qi: float -> Internal Q 5. Sij: [complexIQ]/(amplitude,phase) -> Sij data ; either for a single power or multiple power levels 6. Pow: float -> Power level 7. Temp: float -> Temperature 8. photon: float -> Number of photons/ corresponding and calculated from power level

Methods : 1. __init__ : Constructor

  1. generate(nop=5000, start_f, stop_f,fr,fano_b) : Generate the resonator model from the given parameters

  2. generate_mw_model(nop=5000, start_f, stop_f,fr,fano_b) : Generate the resonator model from the given parameters using scipy.mw

  3. save(filename) : Save the model to a file using pandas

  4. plot() : Plot the model

  5. load(filename) : Load the model from a file using pandas

Note: # powers < the freqeuncy span of the resonator either 1D or 2D Sij data

add_noise(SNR: float | None = None, to='both') → None[source]

Add noise to the model, Scales the SNR / a or sigma = a x r / SNR

amp_pha2complex(amp, pha) → ndarray[source]

Convert amplitude and phase to complex

property f
property fitparams
property fr
generate(power, start_f=4500000000.0, stop_f=5500000000.0, fano_b=1000000.0)[source]

Generate the resonator model from the given parameters of the specific power level, using the fitparams. Update the fitparams before generate() and this updates the Sij and f based on the fitparams

  • does not care about the power level

  • depends on the SNR can add noise using add_noise(), but generates a very ideal model

generate_mw_model(nop=5000, start_f=4500000000.0, stop_f=5500000000.0, fr=5000000000.0, fano_b=1000000.0)[source]

Generate the resonator model from the given parameters using scipy.mw

Calculate the SNR of the model

validate() → bool[source]

Validate the model, before every generate - validates the parameters changed to generate again; need to call before generate - not needed for the fit
